What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning

Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain
Comments_List: more info about bio instrumentation and techniques
It was interesting to read on the whole "bench-to-bedside" work on drug treatments.
I learned to critically assess literature concerning chemical biology or even fully biologically oriented literature. This is something I would have been less comfortable with before.
I learned a lot more about how to critically analyze papers, and I learned a lot out the field of medicinal chemistry.
I learned about how the pharmaceutical industry works, as well as how drugs are discovered, designed, and optimized.
It was a literature-based survey course on therapeutics and the pharmaceutical industry.

Critical literature reading
Introduction to Chem Bio drug development

Various concepts in chemical biology, with a special emphasis on drug development. For example, how to perform rational drug design, and also new therapies like CAR-T cells. It has a very strong biological focus, so you also end up knowing more about some of the disease mechanisms like HIV, HCV.
I learned a lot of new chemical biology techniques and how to read papers more effectively.
some reading
Some insights into to the process of drug development, from new discoveries to final development and trials
I gained insight into the various phases of drug development.
I acquired a lot of basic knowledge about drug discovery and development. And I was also able to train my presentation skills through preparing for the group presentation
I feel that the pressure of participation wasn't as effective in facilitating discussion. I feel that there would be more effective ways to demonstrate one's level of understanding of the papers.

Having speakers from industry really gives a unique view on certain topics that could not have been obtained otherwise. Oftentimes, the student participation felt quite forced, so I did not really like this part of the course.

If people did not read the articles, it can make the discussion aspect of the course a little more challenging. Also, forcing the class to go around in a circle to answer questions instead of allowing students that have insightful responses to answer the questions, I feel that my education was hindered for the sake of Class Participation.

Strengths: lots of primary literature, fantastic guest speakers, a very applicable and interesting course.
Weaknesses: occasionally there were too many papers assigned for a single week (I think 3-4 is ideal, 5+ is too many to really understand). I thought an unnecessary emphasis was placed on everybody in class participating, frequently students were put on the spot to answer questions about topics they had no experience with.

Strengths:  good selection of papers, great guest speakers, accessible professors, manageable workload.  Weaknesses:  wasn't as much of a discussion seminar as it was quizzing people on the papers, majority of class time seemed like it was spent evaluating students instead of learning anything.
Require more introduction in the basic techniques in literature that might not be familiar to everyone

The topics each week were all well thought out and interesting. Guest lecturers (who all work in industry) gave extremely interesting insights into the drug development process. However, the professors tend to cold call on students to answer questions about very tiny details in the papers we read every week, which made the class quite stressful.

I thought the courses subject matter was interesting, but the seminar format and requirement for every to participate in a discussion often times forced questions that required little digestion and thought over the material being presented.  Often times the questions being asked in class would have been more appropriately asked on a reading quiz rather than in front of the entire class.  Regurgitation of what is stated in the paper is not a discussion.
I liked the variety of topics, but I'm not sure having students present them is the most effective way to facilitate learning the material. I like that it felt like a discussion, though.
student lectures are not good

The topics discussed in this seminar were all  very interesting! I think one weakness of the course was low level of engagement from students. The topics while interesting were seemingly daunting for someone with minimal background in chemical biology. Maybe a brief background/introduction of the topic given by the instructors would have increased participation in the following student presentations.

I think this course is a little demanding for those who haven't taken chemical biology before since it requires you to have some basic knowledge about it. If this course could spend some more time talking about some necessary basic facts it could be more helpful
If students are interested in discussing biological applications in chemistry, yes, I would.
Yes.
Yes. The class covers a wide range of topics that center around medicinal chemistry, and really gives you a good overview of that field.
Absolutely. I think this class is excellent for anyone who plans to do chemistry or biology and work in topics related to health.

Yeah I'd recommend it.  Its a bit of a weird class, so keep that in mind.  Its a seminar with a heavy amount of class participation factored into the grade, but dont expect too much actual discussion about the field - its basically just reading papers before class and then having presenters cold call students to recite the details.  Both professors are great resources though, and the critical analysis of the literature combined with the really insightful guest lecturers make this course worth taking.

Take this class - it's really fun and you learn a lot from the scientific papers that the professors assign every week. It also trains you to read the papers in a very detailed manner, and critically consider their methodology and results.
Yes. I thought it was super fun, and I learned a lot of interesting science
no
Yes
If you are interested in drug discovery it could be a good choice
